Input.threadtitle: gradient descent algorithm
Input.posts:
Hi all, I've just finished watching the week 1 videos and I have a few questions. 1/ How to ensure the convergence of the gradient descent algorithm? It seems that choosing a small step is not a good idea as it could take forever to converge but on the other hand choosing a large step can make the algorithm diverge. 2/ For such a quadratic/convex fonction than the cost fonction of a regression problem (using mean square error), isn't it just easier to analytically take the derivative and exactly solve for when it equals zero? 3/ As far as vocabulary is concerned, is the linear regression using Mean Square Error (as Andrew presented) the same thing as what is called Ordinary Least Square (as described in the wikipedia article) ? Thanks in advance for your contributions. Damien
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Damien, I will try to answer your questions: 1) If the cost function is convex and the step size is not too large, Gradient Descent is guaranteed to converge to the global minimum. If the step size is too large, Gradient Descent will diverge. 2) You are correct, step size is important. As you go through the course, you will have many opportunities to gain experience in setting this parameter. 3) Yes, he is basically describing Linear Least Squares. (For example, finding the optimal values of m and b in f(x) = mx + b which minimize the sum of the squares of the differences: { f( x[ i ] ) - y[ i ] }. ) 4) Analytically solving for the minimum (this will be covered in the course) is sometimes a good idea, but not always. One problem with analytic solutions is that they are prone to 'overfitting' the data. In practice, another term is usually added to the cost function called a 'regularization' term. The purpose of this term is to prevent overfitting. One example of overfitting is if you were to fit a data set with a high-degree polynomial. Here is an extreme case: if you have five (x,y) pairs of data and fit a 5th order polynomial to these data points, the fitted function will exactly go through each data point, but trying to use this function to compute area-under-the-curve, interpolation, or worse yet, extrapolation outside the [x-min, x-max] range will not be very beneficial. Again, overfitting, regularization, and analytic solutions (such as the Normal Equation) will be discussed in future lectures. I hope this helps!

Hi Amir and and Gustavo, allow me to add few comments to the conversation. (1) To make the discussion easier, let us consider the case of linear regression with one variable. In this case the function to be minimized, $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1)$$, is a polynomial of degree two in $$\theta_0$$ and $$\theta_1$$ (a.k.a. bivariate polynomial of degree 2). For instance $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = 4*\theta_0^2 + 3*\theta_1^2 + \theta_0*\theta_1 + \theta_0 + \theta_1 + 1$$. Since $$J$$ is the sum of squares, then it always takes values that are positive (and in some cases zero, although not always). You might remember that Prof. Ng mentioned that functions like this one when plotted in the $$[\theta_0, \theta_1, J(\theta_0, \theta_1)]$$ coordinate system look like a bowl--with its base resting on the table, so to speak(*) (2) Now, when finding an approximation of the only minimum for functions with these properties, the gradient descent algorithm (GDA) is pretty good. Therefore, the main reason why Prof. Ng is using the GDA is not didactic. Although the approach he follows to present the algorithm is very didactic (e.g., notice that he first gives the intuition for real functions of one variable, and then considers real functions of two variables--which is the case of linear regression with just one feature.) (3) Now, about the question of whether the Newton-Raphson Method (NRM) can be used to solve the problem of minimizing $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1)$$ ... the short answer is yes ... but not directly (as it is the case of the GDA). First, recall the NRM has been originally proposed to solve the problem: find $$x$$ in the Real interval $$[a,b]$$, such that $$f(x) = 0$$; provided $$f$$ is a real-valued, differentiable function in the given interval. Therefore, notice that $$f$$ is a real-valued function of $$\bf one$$ variable. Also, notice this problem is constrained to finding $$x$$ in the given interval. (4) So, one way to use the NRM to solve the optimization problem is by trying to solve: find $$\theta$$, such that the 'derivative' of $$J(\theta)$$ is zero. Notice that in this case $$\theta$$ is a vector (not a single real value, as in the classical format of the NRM); in this case $$\theta = [\theta_0 \theta_1]^T$$ (seen as a column vector). Therefore, we need to answer the questions: (a) what is the 'interval' for $$\theta$$ (which is a vector)? (b) what is the 'derivative' of $$J$$? (5) Once we answer (4-a) and (4-b) we still need to answer the questions: (a) what is the 'derivative' of the 'derivative' of $$J$$? (b) what would be the equivalent to the term in the NRM: $$\frac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)}$$? (6) Answering the questions in (4) and (5) above does require a little bit of detail. If you are interested in seeing the details, you might want to see, for instance: http://www.stat.washington.edu/adobra/classes/536/Files/week1/newtonfull.pdf (7) Regardless of the details, it seems that for minimizing functions of the type of the $$J$$ associated with linear regression (with one or more features), the GDA would be more efficient than the NRM simply because the former just needs the 'derivative' of $$J$$, but not its second 'derivative'. Prof. Ng will soon talk about 'the gradient', which is the derivative of $$J$$ (so you can see why people call this algorithm 'gradient' descent). (8) Finally, and excuse the long discussion, it turns out that for the $$J$$ in linear regression (with one or more features), since it is easy to compute the gradient of $$J$$ (its 'derivative', written $$\nabla J$$), the problem of finding $$\theta$$ such that $$\nabla J(\theta) = 0$$, is equivalent to finding the solution of a system of linear equations, called 'normal equations', which can be solved without having to compute the second derivative of $$J$$. Prof. Ng covers this in one of his videos. I hope you will find the comments useful, albeit long (please excuse me for that!) Cheers! (*) Just in case you have not used Wolfram Alpha before ... ( https://www.wolframalpha.com/ ) ... try going there and type: plot 4*x^2 + 3*y^2 + x*y + x + 1 and see the plot you get ...

Hi Amir and and Gustavo, allow me to add few comments to the conversation. (1) To make the discussion easier, let us consider the case of linear regression with one variable. In this case the function to be minimized, $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1)$$, is a polynomial of degree two in $$\theta_0$$ and $$\theta_1$$ (a.k.a. bivariate polynomial of degree 2). For instance $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = 4*\theta_0^2 + 3*\theta_1^2 + \theta_0*\theta_1 + \theta_0 + \theta_1 + 1$$. Since $$J$$ is the sum of squares, then it always takes values that are positive (and in some cases zero, although not always). You might remember that Prof. Ng mentioned that functions like this one when plotted in the $$[\theta_0, \theta_1, J(\theta_0, \theta_1)]$$ coordinate system look like a bowl--with its base resting on the table, so to speak(*) (2) Now, when finding an approximation of the only minimum for functions with these properties, the gradient descent algorithm (GDA) is pretty good. Therefore, the main reason why Prof. Ng is using the GDA is not didactic. Although the approach he follows to present the algorithm is very didactic (e.g., notice that he first gives the intuition for real functions of one variable, and then considers real functions of two variables--which is the case of linear regression with just one feature.) (3) Now, about the question of whether the Newton-Raphson Method (NRM) can be used to solve the problem of minimizing $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1)$$ ... the short answer is yes ... but not directly (as it is the case of the GDA). First, recall the NRM has been originally proposed to solve the problem: find $$x$$ in the Real interval $$[a,b]$$, such that $$f(x) = 0$$; provided $$f$$ is a real-valued, differentiable function in the given interval. Therefore, notice that $$f$$ is a real-valued function of $$\bf one$$ variable. Also, notice this problem is constrained to finding $$x$$ in the given interval. (4) So, one way to use the NRM to solve the optimization problem is by trying to solve: find $$\theta$$, such that the 'derivative' of $$J(\theta)$$ is zero. Notice that in this case $$\theta$$ is a vector (not a single real value, as in the classical format of the NRM); in this case $$\theta = [\theta_0 \theta_1]^T$$ (seen as a column vector). Therefore, we need to answer the questions: (a) what is the 'interval' for $$\theta$$ (which is a vector)? (b) what is the 'derivative' of $$J$$? (5) Once we answer (4-a) and (4-b) we still need to answer the questions: (a) what is the 'derivative' of the 'derivative' of $$J$$? (b) what would be the equivalent to the term in the NRM: $$\frac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)}$$? (6) Answering the questions in (4) and (5) above does require a little bit of detail. If you are interested in seeing the details, you might want to see, for instance: http://www.stat.washington.edu/adobra/classes/536/Files/week1/newtonfull.pdf (7) Regardless of the details, it seems that for minimizing functions of the type of the $$J$$ associated with linear regression (with one or more features), the GDA would be more efficient than the NRM simply because the former just needs the 'derivative' of $$J$$, but not its second 'derivative'. Prof. Ng will soon talk about 'the gradient', which is the derivative of $$J$$ (so you can see why people call this algorithm 'gradient' descent). (8) Finally, and excuse the long discussion, it turns out that for the $$J$$ in linear regression (with one or more features), since it is easy to compute the gradient of $$J$$ (its 'derivative', written $$\nabla J$$), the problem of finding $$\theta$$ such that $$\nabla J(\theta) = 0$$, is equivalent to finding the solution of a system of linear equations, called 'normal equations', which can be solved without having to compute the second derivative of $$J$$. Prof. Ng covers this in one of his videos. I hope you will find the comments useful, albeit long (please excuse me for that!) Cheers! (*) Just in case you have not used Wolfram Alpha before ... ( https://www.wolframalpha.com/ ) ... try going there and type: plot 4*x^2 + 3*y^2 + x*y + x + 1 and see the plot you get ...

The question you're trying to answer here is 'how many items do I expect to sell over the coming month?' As you correctly said, it's about the percentage likely to be sold x the size of the inventory (= expected sales). The size of the inventory is known, but what is unknown is the percentage likely to be sold . This percentage is a continuous value, which makes it a regression problem. Presumably, the items in the inventory are identical, which means it's not practical to classify each item into 'likely to be sold' or 'not likely to be sold' individually. They all have the same probability to get sold, and it again comes down to the expected total number at the end of the month to determine this probability.
